Package com.github.tommyettinger.tweenmachine

Class BaseTween<T extends BaseTween<T>>

java.lang.Object
com.github.tommyettinger.tweenmachine.BaseTween<T>
Direct Known Subclasses:
Timeline, Tween
public abstract class BaseTween<T extends BaseTween<T>> extends Object
BaseTween is the base class of Tween and Timeline. It defines the iteration engine used to play animations for any number of times, and in any direction, at any speed.

It is responsible for calling the different callbacks at the right moments, and for making sure that every callback is triggered, even if the update engine gets a big delta time at once.

See Also:
  • Tween
  • Timeline

  • Constructor Details

  • Method Details

    • reset

      protected void reset()

    • build

      public BaseTween<T> build()
      Builds and validates the object. Only needed if you want to finalize a tween or timeline without starting it, since a call to ".start()" also calls this method.
      Returns:
      The current object, for chaining instructions.

    • start

      public BaseTween<T> start()
      Starts or restarts the object unmanaged. You will need to take care of its life-cycle. If you want the tween to be managed for you, use a TweenManager.
      Returns:
      The current object, for chaining instructions.

    • start

      public BaseTween<T> start(TweenManager manager)
      Convenience method to add an object to a manager. Its life-cycle will be handled for you. Relax and enjoy the animation.
      Returns:
      The current object, for chaining instructions.

    • delay

      public BaseTween<T> delay(float delay)
      Adds a delay to the tween or timeline.
      Parameters:
      delay - A duration.
      Returns:
      The current object, for chaining instructions.

    • kill

      public void kill()
      Kills the tween or timeline. If you are using a TweenManager, this object will be removed automatically.

    • free

      public void free()
      Stops and resets the tween or timeline, and sends it to its pool, for + * later reuse. Note that if you use a TweenManager, this method + * is automatically called once the animation is finished.

    • pause

      public void pause()
      Pauses the tween or timeline. Further update calls won't have any effect.

    • resume

      public void resume()
      Resumes the tween or timeline. Has no effect is it was no already paused.

    • repeat

      public BaseTween<T> repeat(int count, float delay)
      Repeats the tween or timeline for a given number of times.
      Parameters:
      count - The number of repetitions. For infinite repetition, use Tween.INFINITY, or a negative number.
      delay - A delay between each iteration.
      Returns:
      The current tween or timeline, for chaining instructions.

    • repeatYoyo

      public BaseTween<T> repeatYoyo(int count, float delay)
      Repeats the tween or timeline for a given number of times. Every two iterations, it will be played backwards.
      Parameters:
      count - The number of repetitions. For infinite repetition, use Tween.INFINITY, or a negative number.
      delay - A delay before each repetition.
      Returns:
      The current tween or timeline, for chaining instructions.

    • setCallback

      public BaseTween<T> setCallback(TweenCallback callback)
      Sets the callback. By default, it will be fired at the completion of the tween or timeline (event COMPLETE). If you want to change this behavior and add more triggers, use the setCallbackTriggers(int) method.
      See Also:
      • TweenCallback

    • setCallbackTriggers

      public BaseTween<T> setCallbackTriggers(int flags)
      Changes the triggers of the callback. The available triggers, listed as members of the TweenCallback interface, are:

      BEGIN: right after the delay (if any)
      START: at each iteration beginning
      END: at each iteration ending, before the repeat delay
      COMPLETE: at last END event
      BACK_BEGIN: at the beginning of the first backward iteration
      BACK_START: at each backward iteration beginning, after the repeat delay
      BACK_END: at each backward iteration ending
      BACK_COMPLETE: at last BACK_END event 

       
 forward :      BEGIN                                   COMPLETE
 forward :      START    END      START    END      START    END
 |--------------[XXXXXXXXXX]------[XXXXXXXXXX]------[XXXXXXXXXX]
 backward:      bEND  bSTART      bEND  bSTART      bEND  bSTART
 backward:      bCOMPLETE                                 bBEGIN
      Parameters:
      flags - one or more triggers, separated by the '|' operator.
      See Also:
      • TweenCallback

    • setUserData

      public BaseTween<T> setUserData(Object data)
      Attaches an object to this tween or timeline. It can be useful in order to retrieve some data from a TweenCallback.
      Parameters:
      data - Any kind of object.
      Returns:
      The current tween or timeline, for chaining instructions.

    • getDelay

      public float getDelay()
      Gets the delay of the tween or timeline. Nothing will happen before this delay.

    • getDuration

      public float getDuration()
      Gets the duration of a single iteration.

    • getRepeatCount

      public int getRepeatCount()
      Gets the number of iterations that will be played.

    • getRepeatDelay

      public float getRepeatDelay()
      Gets the delay occurring between two iterations.

    • getFullDuration

      public float getFullDuration()
      Returns the complete duration, including initial delay and repetitions. The formula is as follows: 
       fullDuration = delay + duration + (repeatDelay + duration) * repeatCnt

    • getUserData

      public Object getUserData()
      Gets the attached data, or null if none.

    • getStep

      public int getStep()
      Gets the id of the current step. Values are as follows:
      • even numbers mean that an iteration is playing,
      • odd numbers mean that we are between two iterations,
      • -2 means that the initial delay has not ended,
      • -1 means that we are before the first iteration,
      • repeatCount*2 + 1 means that we are after the last iteration

    • getCurrentTime

      public float getCurrentTime()
      Gets the local time.

    • isStarted

      public boolean isStarted()
      Returns true if the tween or timeline has been started.

    • isInitialized

      public boolean isInitialized()
      Returns true if the tween or timeline has been initialized. Starting values for tweens are stored at initialization time. This initialization takes place right after the initial delay, if any.

    • isFinished

      public boolean isFinished()
      Returns true if the tween is finished (i.e. if the tween has reached its end or has been killed). If you don't use a TweenManager, you may want to call free() to reuse the object later.

    • isYoyo

      public boolean isYoyo()
      Returns true if the iterations are played as yoyo. Yoyo means that every two iterations, the animation will be played backwards.

    • isPaused

      public boolean isPaused()
      Returns true if the tween or timeline is currently paused.

    • forceStartValues

      protected abstract void forceStartValues()

    • forceEndValues

      protected abstract void forceEndValues()

    • containsTarget

      protected abstract boolean containsTarget(Object target)

    • containsTarget

      protected abstract boolean containsTarget(Object target, int tweenType)

    • updateOverride

      protected boolean isValid(int step)

    • killTarget

      protected void killTarget(Object target)

    • killTarget

      protected void killTarget(Object target, int tweenType)

    • update

      public void update(float delta)
      Updates the tween or timeline state. You may want to use a TweenManager to update objects for you.
      Slow motion, fast motion and backward play can be easily achieved by tweaking this delta time. Multiply it by -1 to play the animation backward, or by 0.5 to play it twice slower than its normal speed.
      Parameters:
      delta - A delta time between now and the last call.
